channel.title: Nature
channel.description: Nature publishes peer-reviewed original research of the highest quality in all areas of cell biology with an emphasis on studies that provide insights into the molecular mechanisms underlying cellular processes. The journal’s scope is broad and ranges from cytoskeletal dynamics, membrane transport, adhesion and migration, cell division, signalling pathways, development and stem cells, to molecular and cellular mechanisms underlying cancer. Nature Cell Biology provides timely and informative coverage of cell biological advances.
channel.dc:rights: © 2023 Sebastien Lemaire Production. All rights reserved.

item.title: Light from cosmic dawn hints at how interstellar dust is made
item.description: The obscuration of light from a distant galaxy has raised the possibility that a type of carbon dust existed in the earliest epochs of the Universe — challenging the idea that stars had not yet evolved enough to make such material.
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 2023-09-12; doi:doi.org/d41586-023-02766-4

Light from cosmic dawn hints at how interstellar dust is made
item.dc:title: Light from cosmic dawn hints at how interstellar dust is made
item.dc:creator: Xuejuan Yang
Aigen Li

item.title: From the archive: the value of MSc degrees, and painting tips
item.description: Snippets from Nature’s past.
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 2023-09-12; doi:doi.org/d41586-023-02769-1

From the archive: the value of MSc degrees, and painting tips
item.dc:title: From the archive: the value of MSc degrees, and painting tips

item.title: Surface interaction propels molecule forwards
item.description: The interaction of a molecule with a specific surface has been shown to produce consistent unidirectional motion driven by voltage pulses. The mechanism can even facilitate the transport of molecular cargo.
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 2023-09-06; doi:doi.org/d41586-023-02565-x

Surface interaction propels molecule forwards
item.dc:title: Surface interaction propels molecule forwards
item.dc:creator: Leo Gross
Jascha Repp

item.title: Dynamic regulation of messenger RNA structure controls translation
item.description: During translation, messenger RNA guides protein production, and certain conditions can favour particular proteins. Helicase enzymes and mRNA structure control translation during defence responses in plants.
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 2023-09-06; doi:doi.org/d41586-023-02673-8

Dynamic regulation of messenger RNA structure controls translation
item.dc:title: Dynamic regulation of messenger RNA structure controls translation
item.dc:creator: Yizhu Lin
Stephen N. Floor

item.title: Cardiac cycle inspires optimized pipe flow
item.description: Pulsatile driving of pipe flow that imitates waveforms measured in the human aorta has been shown to suppress turbulence and increase the energy efficiency of the transport of fluids in pipes.
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 2023-09-06; doi:doi.org/d41586-023-02739-7

Cardiac cycle inspires optimized pipe flow
item.dc:title: Cardiac cycle inspires optimized pipe flow
item.dc:creator: Angela Busse

item.title: From the archive: enchanting insects, and John Stuart Mill’s will
item.description: Snippets from Nature’s past.
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 2023-09-05; doi:doi.org/d41586-023-02738-8

From the archive: enchanting insects, and John Stuart Mill’s will
item.dc:title: From the archive: enchanting insects, and John Stuart Mill’s will

item.title: A drowned future for coastal ecosystems
item.description: Tidal marshes, mangroves and coral reefs support the livelihoods of millions of people. Most of these ecosystems will be vulnerable to submergence owing to rapid sea-level rise if global warming exceeds 2 °C above pre-industrial levels.
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 2023-08-30; doi:doi.org/d41586-023-02595-5

A drowned future for coastal ecosystems
item.dc:title: A drowned future for coastal ecosystems
item.dc:creator: Qiang He

item.title: Dynamic ion channel defies dogma
item.description: It is well established that proteins in the TRP family of ion channels assemble from four subunits. But do they always do this? A five-subunit structure has now been observed, and might be involved in channel regulation.
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 2023-08-30; doi:doi.org/d41586-023-02486-9

Dynamic ion channel defies dogma
item.dc:title: Dynamic ion channel defies dogma
item.dc:creator: Ute A. Hellmich

item.title: Previously unknown pathway for lipid biosynthesis discovered
item.description: The pathway used by mammalian cells to make triglyceride lipids when supplies of fat molecules are high has long been known. A route that works when fat supplies are low has now been discovered.
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 2023-08-30; doi:doi.org/d41586-023-02502-y

Previously unknown pathway for lipid biosynthesis discovered
item.dc:title: Previously unknown pathway for lipid biosynthesis discovered
item.dc:creator: Jean E. Schaffer

item.title: Rethinking the effect of marine heatwaves on fish
item.description: Marine heatwaves are on the rise. A surprising result from the analysis of data for fish populations in Europe and North America could change ways of thinking about the ecological consequences of such events.
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 2023-08-30; doi:doi.org/d41586-023-02594-6

Rethinking the effect of marine heatwaves on fish
item.dc:title: Rethinking the effect of marine heatwaves on fish
item.dc:creator: Mark R. Payne

item.title: Drone-racing champions outpaced by AI
item.description: An autonomous drone has competed against human drone-racing champions — and won. The victory can be attributed to savvy engineering and a type of artificial intelligence that learns mostly through trial and error.
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 2023-08-30; doi:doi.org/d41586-023-02506-8

Drone-racing champions outpaced by AI
item.dc:title: Drone-racing champions outpaced by AI
item.dc:creator: Guido C. H. E. de Croon

item.title: Heaviest oxygen isotope is found to be unbound
item.description: The isotope oxygen-28 is expected to be ‘doubly magic’, with strongly bound neutrons and protons in its nucleus. Experiments now reveal that it exists in an unbound state — casting doubt on its magic status.
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 2023-08-30; doi:doi.org/d41586-023-02485-w

Heaviest oxygen isotope is found to be unbound
item.dc:title: Heaviest oxygen isotope is found to be unbound
item.dc:creator: Rituparna Kanungo

item.description: Snippets from Nature’s past.

From the archive: colour constancy, and an atomic romance
item.dc:title: From the archive: colour constancy, and an atomic romance

item.title: Corals have algal friends for dinner
item.description: Biologists have long sought to understand the factors that enable coral reefs to thrive. A careful analysis of nutrient cycling now points to an unexpected food source that helps to sustain corals during food scarcity.
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 2023-08-23; doi:doi.org/d41586-023-02593-7

Corals have algal friends for dinner
item.dc:title: Corals have algal friends for dinner
item.dc:creator: Virginia M. Weis

item.title: Brain implants that enable speech pass performance milestones
item.description: Two brain–computer interfaces have been developed that bring unprecedented capabilities for translating brain signals into sentences — at speeds close to that of normal speech, and with vocabularies exceeding 1,000 words.
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 2023-08-23; doi:doi.org/d41586-023-02546-0

Brain implants that enable speech pass performance milestones
item.dc:title: Brain implants that enable speech pass performance milestones
item.dc:creator: Nick F. Ramsey
Nathan E. Crone

item.title: Analog chip paves the way for sustainable AI
item.description: As the resources required by artificial intelligence increase unsustainably, an analog design provides an energy-efficient alternative to digital computer chips — and one that is ideally suited to neural-network computations.
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 2023-08-23; doi:doi.org/d41586-023-02569-7

Analog chip paves the way for sustainable AI
item.dc:title: Analog chip paves the way for sustainable AI
item.dc:creator: Hechen Wang

item.title: Satellite images show the widespread impact of mining on tropical rivers
item.description: A careful analysis of satellite images has revealed marked changes in the suspended-sediment concentrations of many rivers around the world. The study links these changes directly to river mining activities in the affected areas.
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 2023-08-23; doi:doi.org/d41586-023-02349-3

Satellite images show the widespread impact of mining on tropical rivers
item.dc:title: Satellite images show the widespread impact of mining on tropical rivers
item.dc:creator: Bryony Walmsley

From the archive: Copernicus’s legacy, and a hungry pigeon
item.dc:title: From the archive: Copernicus’s legacy, and a hungry pigeon

item.title: The great melt will shape unprotected ecosystems
item.description: Glaciers should be prioritized in conservation agendas — and soon. Analysis suggests that glaciers could lose around half their area by the century’s end, with uncertain consequences for postglacial ecosystems.
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 2023-08-16; doi:doi.org/d41586-023-02490-z

The great melt will shape unprotected ecosystems
item.dc:title: The great melt will shape unprotected ecosystems
item.dc:creator: Nicolas Lecomte

item.title: Clues to rain formation found in droplet images
item.description: X-ray and optical imaging have revealed the intricate process through which droplets freeze during the formation of rain. The results could help to explain how clouds are able to produce enough ice particles to make rain.
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 2023-08-16; doi:doi.org/d41586-023-02353-7

Clues to rain formation found in droplet images
item.dc:title: Clues to rain formation found in droplet images
item.dc:creator: Thomas Leisner
